identificationModule.briefTitle: Do Terpenes Play a Role in the Stress-reducing Effects of a Forest Bathing Intervention?
identificationModule.officialTitle: Do Terpenes Play a Role in the Stress-reducing Effects of a Forest Bathing Intervention?

responsibleParty.investigatorTitle: Assistant Professor: Environmental and Forest Sciences

collaborators.name: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This pilot study evaluates the role terpenes play in the stress-reducing effects of a forest bathing intervention. Participants will participate in two interventions in random order: 1) terpene exposure and 2) no terpene exposure.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
The investigators will use an individual-level crossover design in which each session is conducted independently and on different days. Participants will be outfitted with a powered air purifying respirator (PAPR) to selectively modulate exposure to a natural suite of forest-derived volatile organic compounds (VOCs) while present in forest environments. Each participant will undergo two forest bathing sessions, one in which VOCs are not filtered (treatment condition), and one in which they are filtered (control condition). Sessions will be separated by a 7-day washout period for each participant, and order will be counterbalanced. The investigators will estimate the average effect of treatment over 40 distinct treatment days against 40 distinct control/filtered days. The power and sample size calculations (N = 40) were determined using previous nature exposure studies of similar cross-over design. The study is adequately powered assuming the conventional targets of α = 0.05 and β = 0.80 with a 10% anticipated dropout rate, and including temperature, wind, and light variability during treatment days.

The specific aim of this project is to 1) assess whether VOC inhalation regulates increases in the high frequency (HF) (ms2) component of heart rate variability (HRV) as the primary outcome (with decreases in blood pressure, heart rate, self-reported stress, and levels of inflammatory cytokines in serum included as secondary outcomes); and 1a) assess the degree of association of absorbed dose of seven forest-derived VOCs in serum (i.e., α-pinene, β-pinene, β-myrcene, ∆ 3-carene, d-limonene, β- caryophyllene, α-humulene) with these outcomes.

conditions: Monoterpene Exposure During a Forest Bathing Intervention

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Participants are assigned to both arms in random order

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: Participants and research staff conducting the intervention will be masked to the exposure

armGroups.label: Terpenes On
armGroups.description: Forest bathing intervention with no filtration of terpenes from inhaled air ("terpenes on")

armGroups.label: Terpenes Off
armGroups.description: Forest bathing intervention with filtration of terpenes from inhaled air ("terpenes off")

interventions.name: Forest bathing
interventions.description: Participants will be seated in a forest environment for an hour-long exposure to the forest

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes in the HF (ms2) component of HRV
primaryOutcomes.description: Assess whether VOC inhalation regulates psychophysiological outcomes of the terpenes-on vs. terpenes-off sessions.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: up to 1 hour before the forest bathing session, during the forest bathing session (1 hr), and up to 1 hour following the forest bathing session (1hr).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Blood pressure (systolic and diastolic in mmHg)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: up to 2.5 hours before the forest bathing session, during the forest bathing session (1 hr), and up to 1 hour following the forest bathing session (1hr).
up to 2.5 hours before the forest bathing session, during the forest bathing session (1 hr), and up to 1 hour following the forest bathing session (1hr).
up to 2.5 hours before the forest bathing session, during the forest bathing session (1 hr), and up to 1 hour following the forest bathing session (1hr).

secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the shortened Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) and/or Profile of Mood States (POMS)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: up to 2.5 hours before the forest bathing session, during the forest bathing session (1 hr), and up to 1 hour following the forest bathing session (1hr).

secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using the shortened State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: up to 2.5 hours before the forest bathing session, during the forest bathing session (1 hr), and up to 1 hour following the forest bathing session (1hr).
up to 2.5 hours before the forest bathing session, during the forest bathing session (1 hr), and up to 1 hour following the forest bathing session (1hr).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Levels of inflammatory cytokines (CRP, TNF-alpha, and IL-6 in μg/mL)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using blood serum collected via standard clinical methods
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 1 hour before the forest bathing session (1 hr); up to 1 hour after the forest bathing session (1 hr)

secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessed using blood serum collected via standard clinical methods
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 1 hour before the forest bathing session (1 hr); up to 1 hour after the forest bathing session (1 hr)

otherOutcomes.measure: Degree of association of absorbed dose of VOCs in serum (μg/mL)
otherOutcomes.description: Assess the degree of association of absorbed dose of seven forest-derived VOCs in serum (i.e., α-pinene, β-pinene, β-myrcene, ∆ 3- carene, d-limonene, β-caryophyllene, α-humulene) with primary and secondary outcomes.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 1 hour before the forest bathing session (1 hr); up to 1 hour after the forest bathing session (1 hr)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* 18 years and older
* Non-smoker
* Physically capable of walking for approximately 15-20 min from the study vehicle to the clinic and experimental locations.

Exclusion Criteria:

* Pregnancy
* Current or prior diagnosis of neurologic, hypertensive, psychiatric, respiratory disorder, or anosmia/hyposmia
* Some types of medication.
* Olfactory sensitivity threshold (assessed via UPSIT® test kit (Sensonics International, Haddon Heights, NJ)
* Positive COVID-19 test

At enrollment, participants will complete a baseline survey on demographics, personality traits, and regular nature contact and perceptions. Study staff will also use the clinically-validated UPSIT® test kit (Sensonics International, Haddon Heights, NJ) to evaluate olfactory sensitivity and identify/exclude participants with undiagnosed smell loss.

Study staff will work with participants to schedule their forest bathing sessions and review instructions on how to prepare (e.g., by avoiding alcohol, marijuana, and certain foods, drinks, and household cleaning products with high terpene concentrations 24 hrs before their session).

unpostedAnnotation.unpostedResponsibleParty: Gregory Bratman, Assistant Professor: Environmental and Forest Sciences, University of Washington
